intro: Corylus serotina, commonly known as the late hazelnut, is a deciduous shrub native to eastern North America. It belongs to the family Betulaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and edible nuts. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in woodland areas. Its flowers are unisexual, with male and female flowers on separate plants. The nuts mature in late summer to early autumn, providing food for various wildlife species.
